title: Decimal Fractions to Binary
description: Master converting decimal fractions into binary representation.

sections.title: Converting Decimal Fractions to Binary
sections.content:
Converting decimal fractions to binary uses a different method than whole numbers. We use the **multiply by 2** method!

**Multiply by 2 Method:**

1. Take the fractional part only
2. Multiply by 2
3. Write down the integer part (0 or 1)
4. Keep the fractional remainder
5. Repeat until remainder is 0 or desired precision
6. Read the integer parts from TOP to BOTTOM

**Example 1: Convert 0.625 to binary**

0.625 × 2 = 1.25 → integer part: **1**, remainder: 0.25
0.25 × 2 = 0.5 → integer part: **0**, remainder: 0.5
0.5 × 2 = 1.0 → integer part: **1**, remainder: 0.0

Reading top to bottom: 0.101
So 0.625 in decimal = 0.101 in binary!

**Example 2: Convert 0.75 to binary**

0.75 × 2 = 1.5 → integer part: **1**, remainder: 0.5
0.5 × 2 = 1.0 → integer part: **1**, remainder: 0.0

Result: 0.11
So 0.75 in decimal = 0.11 in binary!

**Example 3: Convert 2.75 to binary**

Handle separately:
Whole part: 2 = 10 (binary)
Fractional: 0.75 = 0.11 (binary)
Combined: 10.11

**Example 4: 0.1 (repeating binary)**

0.1 × 2 = 0.2 → **0**, remainder: 0.2
0.2 × 2 = 0.4 → **0**, remainder: 0.4
0.4 × 2 = 0.8 → **0**, remainder: 0.8
0.8 × 2 = 1.6 → **1**, remainder: 0.6
0.6 × 2 = 1.2 → **1**, remainder: 0.2 (repeats!)

Result: 0.00011001100... (infinite)
This is why 0.1 can't be exact in binary!

**Pro Tips:**
• Convert whole and fractional parts separately
• Read bits from TOP to BOTTOM (opposite of whole number conversion!)
• Stop when remainder is 0 or at desired precision
• Some fractions will repeat infinitely

questions.questionText: When converting decimal fractions to binary, you multiply by ____.
questions.explanation: You multiply by 2 repeatedly, taking the integer part each time as the next binary digit.

questions.questionText: When converting fractions, you read the bits from top to bottom.
questions.explanation: True! This is opposite from whole numbers. The first multiplication gives the first bit after the point.

questions.questionText: Which decimal fraction CANNOT be exactly represented in binary?
questions.explanation: 0.1 requires infinite repeating bits in binary (0.000110011...). Powers of 2 fractions (0.5, 0.25, 0.125) convert exactly.

questions.questionText: All decimal fractions can be perfectly represented in binary with finite digits.
questions.explanation: False! Only fractions that are sums of powers of 2 (like 0.5, 0.75, 0.625) can be exact. Others like 0.1 or 0.3 require infinite bits.
